objects.name: Abuse 'Invites'
objects.description: Adversaries utilize invites to gain access to data

objects.name: Abuse Account Recovery Flows
objects.description: Adversaries use account recovery flows to gain additional information such as contact points or usernames.

objects.name: Abuse Cached Data
objects.description: Adversaries access data that is cached. Adversaries may choose this method to avoid directly querying the platform.

objects.name: Abuse Error Handling Messages
objects.description: Adversaries leverage information or behavior disclosed by error handling messages to learn secret information

objects.name: Abuse Machine Learning Models
objects.description: Adversaries manipulate machine learning models such as recommendation systems to return information from the platform.

objects.name: Abuse Misconfigured Platform Privacy Policies
objects.description: Adversaries take advantage of misconfigured privacy policies offered by the platform. For example, a user might set their birthday to be public when they mean for the setting to be private.

objects.name: Abuse Real-time Communications
objects.description: Adversaries abuse real-time communications to obtain data about others. For example, when communicating with others using peer-to-peer protocols such as WebRTC, IP addresses may be collected.

objects.name: Abuse Redirects
objects.description: Adversaries utilize redirects to send traffic to their servers and steal personal data.

objects.name: Abuse Typeahead Suggestions
objects.description: Adversaries leverage typeahead suggestions to leak information.

objects.name: Access Private Information
objects.description: Adveraries are able to access private information for another user.

objects.name: Access Token Abuse
objects.description: Adversaries utilize access tokens for accessing data

objects.name: Acquire On Platform Assets
objects.description: Adversaries acquire assets on the platform. Assets on the platform such as user accounts may be used to access more data or to promote certain information.

objects.name: Add Contact Points to User Account
objects.description: Adversaries add additional contact points (e.g. email, phone) to a user's account to allow for future adversary access.

objects.name: Artificial Engagement
objects.description: Adversaries create artificial engagement to reach a larger audience. Possible motivations include increasing visibility on their posts or attempting to appear legitimate through high engagement count.

objects.name: Authenticate Through Automation
objects.description: Adversaries use automation to log in to the platform

objects.name: Brute Force
objects.description: Adversaries use brute force to defeat a system. Examples include brute forcing confirmation codes or brute forcing passwords for a login.

objects.name: Build Dataset
objects.description: Adversaries save accessed data from the platform to build their own dataset. The dataset can then be used for other purposes such as selling for profit or further processing.

objects.name: Bypass 2FA
objects.description: Adversaries bypass second factor authentication to gain access.

objects.name: Bypass Authentication Controls
objects.description: Adversaries bypass authentication controls, allowing them to authenticate as another user.

objects.name: Bypass SPAM Filter/Controls
objects.description: Adversaries evade spam filters and controls to reach a wider audience.

objects.name: Change User Settings
objects.description: Adversaries change a user's settings. For example, a user's privacy settings may be changed to a more public one

objects.name: Circumvent Platform Controls
objects.description: Adversaries circumvent platform controls to maintain access to the platform. For example, adversaries may try to post on their fake accounts every month to appear like real users.

objects.name: Collect Platform Metrics
objects.description: Adversaries collect and use data provided by the platform.

objects.name: Combine Datasets
objects.description: Adversaries mix user data is with other sources to draw deeper conclusions.

objects.name: Compromise User Account
objects.description: TBD

objects.name: Create End User GUI
objects.description: Adversaries create end-user Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) to interface with targets. The GUIs are more user-friendly to facilitate the target's interaction. These malicious GUIs often mislead the target to perform certain actions.

objects.name: Create Malicious App
objects.description: Malicious applications are created by adversaries to install on their targets' device. The malicious applications may collect user data and send the data to the adversary

objects.name: Cross Platform Abuse
objects.description: Adversaries utilize assets outside of intended platform for unintended actions. For example, adversaries use test accounts for one platform to perform actions on another platform.

objects.name: Data Inference
objects.description: Adversaries use data to infer information about users.

objects.name: Deanonymization
objects.description: Adversaries de-anonymize and/or re-identify users from a dataset that was assumed to be anonymized or pseudonymized.

objects.name: Delete User Data
objects.description: Adversaries delete a user's data.

objects.name: Enumerate Contact Points
objects.description: Adversaries attempt to enumerate contact points such as phone numbers and email addresses. Contact points may be used to contact the user or used to identify the user.

objects.name: Enumerate On-Platform Accounts
objects.description: Adversaries attempt to enumerate existing accounts on the platform to gauge viable targets for their attack. Enumeration may be achieved through brute forcing or other means.

objects.name: Enumerate On-Platform Assets
objects.description: Adversaries attempt to enumerate existing assets on the platform to gauge viable targets for their attack. Assets that may be targeted include accounts, pages, and groups.

objects.name: Exfiltration
objects.description: Adversaries exfiltrate data from the platform. The data exfiltrated is acquired or exfiltrated through illegitimate means, such as saving shared data outside of agreed upon systems. Data that is obtainable through platform-provided APIs are considered legitimate.

objects.name: Exploit Vulnerability
objects.description: Adversaries leverage vulnerabilities such as cross-site scripting to access data.

objects.name: Extortion
objects.description: Adversaries extort companies or users using data that have gathered to make a profit.

objects.name: Faulty Privacy Policy Implementation
objects.description: Adversaries access data through faulty implementations of privacy policies. For example, attackers may access birthdays set to private on a user profile if the platform implements the privacy policy incorrectly.

objects.name: First Party Tools
objects.description: Adversaries use internal first-party tooling developed by the target company. This may be indicative of a leak or other company compromise. The first-party tools may have additional privileges

objects.name: Forced Engagement
objects.description: Adversaries have users involuntarily engage with their content. For example, users may follow page A that is merged with page B by the adversary, leading to users following page B involuntarily.

objects.name: Freemium Model
objects.description: Adversaries offer a free platform with paid premium features.

objects.name: Geolocate User
objects.description: Adversaries determine geolocation of a user. This may include data that potentially leaks location information such as an IP address.

objects.name: Identify Individuals Belonging to a Group
objects.description: Adversaries attempt to identify the individuals that belong to a group. For example, adversaries may choose to only take further action on users that are within a particular interest group.

objects.name: Identify Rate Limits
objects.description: Adversaries attempt to identify rate limits as part of their reconnaissance process. The rate limit identified may help adversaries evade detection in their later steps.

objects.name: Identify Server Endpoints
objects.description: Adversaries identify server endpoints to understand the attack surface of the platform and the possible points of data egress.

objects.name: Impersonation
objects.description: Adversaries pretend to be another person. Impersonation may be used for multiple purposes, such as to establish trust on a platform as a well-known entity, or to coerce other users into an action.

objects.name: Infer Data From Metrics
objects.description: Metrics such as ad reach estimations and server response timings may be used to infer information such as user interests and existence of assets. Generally metrics come from the platform directly or other first-party sources

objects.name: Integrate Payment Processor
objects.description: Adversaries integrate 3rd party payment processor (e.g. PayPal)

objects.name: Lockout User
objects.description: Adversaries take action to lock a user out of their own account.

objects.name: Logged-in Access
objects.description: Adversaries interact with the platform from a logged-in context.

objects.name: Logged-out Access
objects.description: Adversaries interact with the platform from a logged-out context.

objects.name: Maintain Valid Access Token
objects.description: Adversaries reuse and maintain a valid access token, saving it for prolonged access to the user's account.

objects.name: Monitor Availability Status
objects.description: Adversaries monitor availability status of a user either through on-platform features or through a side-channel. This may be done to understand the active times of a user

objects.name: Obfuscate Identity
objects.description: Adversaries hide their true identity. For example, this may be done to to evade attribution by law enforcement.

objects.name: Obfuscate Tool
objects.description: Adversaries obfuscate their tool so the malicious aspects are not detected, whether it be by an app store or by network defenses.

objects.name: Obtain Access Token
objects.description: Adversaries obtain an access token for another user.

objects.name: Open-source Intelligence
objects.description: Adversaries utilize open-source intelligence (OSINT) to gather information about users or platforms to aid in their attack.

objects.name: Operate Within Rate Limits
objects.description: Adversaries operate within calculated rate limits of an endpoint so that they do not trigger and detections or safeguards.

objects.name: Post Content as User
objects.description: Adversaries masquerade as the user, and use their account to post content.

objects.name: Privilege Escalation
objects.description: Adversaries gain additional privileges on a platform or system to access additional data.

objects.name: Privileged Assets
objects.description: Adversaries use privileged assets that have access to additional systems or data on the platform.

objects.name: Promote Adversarial Tool/Service
objects.description: Adversaries promote their tools or services to reach a wider audience and increase their number of potential targets.

objects.name: Public Unsecured Dataset
objects.description: Adversaries leverage public unsecured datasets. These datasets may contain information such as user IDs or contact points that adversaries can utilize as part of their attack.

objects.name: Publish Data
objects.description: Adversaries publish data as part of their revenue model.

objects.name: Query GraphQL Endpoints
objects.description: Adversaries directly interact with GraphQL endpoints.

objects.name: Read Data From URL
objects.description: Adversaries obtain information directly from a URL

objects.name: Read User Cookies
objects.description: Adversaries gain access to a user cookie, which may allow for the adversary to impersonate the user on-platform.

objects.name: Read User Credentials
objects.description: Adversaries gain access to a users credentials, allowing them to compromise that users account.

objects.name: Recreate On-Platform Enforced Assets
objects.description: Adversaries recreate assets that have been enforced and removed/blocked by the platform to maintain access to the platform.

objects.name: Request Manipulation
objects.description: Adversaries modify requests they have captured or recorded in order to collect desired data. For example, a request may be modified to fetch information about a different user.

objects.name: Reverse Engineer Software
objects.description: Adversaries reverse engineer software to gain information about the platform. Examples of information include white-listed app IDs, persisted GraphQL query document IDs, and legacy endpoints.

objects.name: Run Ads
objects.description: Adversaries distribute advertisements using data they have collected

objects.name: Scraping
objects.description: Adversaries methodically extract data from a platform, at scale.

objects.name: Sell Data
objects.description: Adversaries sell data they have collected from the platform for profit. The data may range from large datasets to data specific to certain individuals.

objects.name: Spoofing
objects.description: Adversaries spoof various pieces of information to hide their characteristics. Not to be confused with impersonation, when adversaries act as another person.

objects.name: Structure/Index Scraped Data
objects.description: Adversaries structure their data for ease of querying and joining with other datasets. For example, a key may be used to uniquely identify entries in a dataset.

objects.name: Subscription Model
objects.description: Adversaries offer a subscription service to the data they have collected

objects.name: Switch Infrastructure
objects.description: Adversaries switch infrastructure to shed identifiers that the platform may have used to identify the attack or adversary identities.

objects.name: Target Outdated Endpoints
objects.description: Outdated endpoints oftentimes have less protections against privacy attacks. Possible causes include failure to update the endpoint according to newer security guidelines or lack of updated logging on the endpoint. Adversaries may choose to target outdated endpoints to due to the potnetial lower bar of entry

objects.name: Targeted Advertising
objects.description: Adversaries use ads targeting to isolate a user or group of users in order to gain engagement from the users

objects.name: Test Anti-abuse Controls
objects.description: Anti abuse controls such as fake account detection and bot detection exist on platforms to prevent abusing the platform. Adversaries try to identify the existence of these controls to better guide later steps in their attack.

objects.name: Use Cloud Infrastructure
objects.description: Cloud infrastructure such as AWS or Digital Ocean provide a method to quickly scale up attacks at a lower cost and help to mask the attacker's IPs

objects.name: Use Device Emulation
objects.description: Adversaries use device emulation to masquerade as a different device with much higher accuracy. For example, adversaries may choose to emulate an iOS device, rather than using a real device.

objects.name: Use Legacy Tools
objects.description: Attackers access the platform from older versions of tools that may not have the same logging and/or restrictions that come with newer versions. For example, older sites may not send as much telemetry about the user's behavior on the site Procedure Example: TBD

objects.name: Use Persisted GraphQL Query
objects.description: Adversaries leverage persisted GraphQL queries that are stored on the server side and referenced by hashes sent by the client instead of sending a full query to the server. This feature aims to restrict the queries that can be queried from the server. Adversaries may still reuse the query for malicious purposes.

objects.name: User Data
objects.description: This technique captures when a user's data has been accessed, with user data being items directly related to a user, such as emails, photos, posts, and reactions. Adversaries may be interested in user data to better understand the demographic and interests of the user

objects.name: Utilize Batched Requests
objects.description: Some endpoints have rate-limits set per request, so batching requests in a single request can sometimes allow attackers to bypass these rate-limits.

objects.name: Utilize Official SDK
objects.description: Adversaries incorporate official software development kits (SDKs) in their attacks to appear more legitimate.

objects.name: Utilize Proxy Service
objects.description: Proxy services tunnel user traffic through an intermediate source before sending the traffic to the platform. By using a proxy, adversaries mingle with legitimate traffic and hide their origin.

objects.name: Virtual Phone Numbers
objects.description: Adversaries use virtual phone numbers for functionality that requires, for example, an SMS verification code. Virtual phone numbers are cheaper to obtain, so the overall cost to scrape is much lower when VoIP numbers are allowed.

objects.name: Abuse Authentication Token Permissions
objects.description: Authentication tokens can contain excessive privileges. By checking the token's permissions, adversaries utilize the token for unintended access to additional (or deprecated) functionality.

objects.name: Abuse CDN links
objects.description: Adversaries access data directly from Content Delivery Network links. Adversaries may utilize this technique to evade logging and expected privacy controls.

objects.name: Abuse Server Side Caching
objects.description: Adversaries leverage cached files on a server to access secret information.

objects.name: Accept Cryptocurrency
objects.description: Adversaries accept cryptocurrencies as a form of payment. Crytocurrencies may be used as a method of anonymization

objects.name: Access Locally Cached Content on Mobile Device
objects.description: Adversaries leverage cached files on the mobile device to access secret information

objects.name: Account Creation With Existing Contact Point
objects.description: Adversaries attempt to signup with contact points for a known target (e.g. email). They use the platform behavior to determine whether this contact point is already associated with an existing account.

objects.name: Account Rotation
objects.description: Adversaries use a pool of accounts to avoid account-based rate limiting or other detection and prevention mechanisms.

objects.name: Ad Reach Estimations
objects.description: Adversaries leverage side channels in ad targeting criteria to learn information about platform users

objects.name: Analyze Image Metadata
objects.description: Adversaries use GPS location tags in EXIF or other similar metadata from media to geolocate users.

objects.name: Android Emulation
objects.description: Adversaries leverage Android emulation as a replacement for attacker hardware or for instrumenting during testing. Some adversary tactics like GPS spoofing may be simpler through an emulator.

objects.name: Archived Site
objects.description: Adversaries leverage archived sites which contain both data and endpoints (current and legacy) that may be used by actors to access data indirectly or discover additional endpoints to target.

objects.name: ASN Rotation
objects.description: Adversaries rotate autonomous system number (ASN) for their infrastructure to avoid correlation or tracking of their interactions with the target platform.

objects.name: Asset Takeover Through Reset
objects.description: Adversaries leverage account resets to take over a user account.

objects.name: Brute Force Confirmation Code
objects.description: Adversaries brute force an account recovery confirmation code, either because the code is too short, the code lacks sufficient entropy or the attacker is allowed too many attempts.

objects.name: CAPTCHA Bypass
objects.description: Adversaries bypass protections offered by CAPTCHA. For example, adversaries might leverage a CAPTCHA bypass service provider.

objects.name: Change Account Credentials
objects.description: Adversaries change account credentials. Adversaries might lock out a user from their account after taking ownership.

objects.name: Cloaking
objects.description: Cloaking is a method to present different content to different users. Adversaries leverage cloaking to mask the true functionality of an abusive entity so the abusive functionality is only available to specific users

objects.name: Clone Site
objects.description: Adversaries leverage "clone" sites that attempt to contain the same information as the original platform in order to redirect traffic to their site.

objects.name: Commenting
objects.description: Adversaries artificially inflate interactivity on social media posts to make them seem more legitimate or otherwise boost their messaging.

objects.name: Copy Content From Local Mobile Device Storage
objects.description: Adversaries access private information by copying contents from a local mobile device

objects.name: Create Account
objects.description: Adversaries create fake accounts on-platform. The accounts may be used as a means to evade rate limits or to engage in artificial engagement

objects.name: Create Browser Extension
objects.description: Adversaries create abusive browser extensions that may contain malicious actions such as collecting user data during web browsing

objects.name: Create Mobile Application
objects.description: Adversaries create abusive mobile appliactions that may contain malicious elements such as fake logins

objects.name: Create Web-based Tool / Service
objects.description: Adversaries create web applications that may contain malicious elements such as stealing user tokens

objects.name: Data Indexed by Search Engines
objects.description: Adversaries use search engines that index sites and store information from platforms. Adversaries may view the stored information through the search engine without interacting with the platform.

objects.name: Derandomization
objects.description: By determining the entropy of a set of generated IDs, adversaries drastically improve the efficiency of brute-force scraping vectors. If the generation of IDs is not truly random, then an attacker may be able to determine the seeding algorithm and brute-force the key space more efficiently

objects.name: Emulate Official Login Dialog
objects.description: Adversaries emulate the official login dialog, usually in an attempt to capture user credentials

objects.name: Encoding
objects.description: Adversaries obfuscate their payloads through encoding to avoid detection systems. For example, a mobile app may fetch encoded code that loads a clone web view login page.

objects.name: Encryption
objects.description: Adversaries obfuscate their payloads through encryption to avoid detection systems. For example, a mobile app may fetch encrypted code that loads a clone web view login page.

objects.name: Escalate Group Membership
objects.description: Adversaries work to escalate their privileges in social groups. Additional privileges may be desired to view the users of a group

objects.name: Exploit Default Field/Configuration To Bleed Data
objects.description: Adversaries take advantage of items that are shown by default. For example, unmasked credit card numbers may be shown due to an error from the platform.

objects.name: Extort Platform
objects.description: Adversaries extort platforms using data they have gathered. For example, attackers may threaten to leak user data to damage a platform's reputation.

objects.name: Extort User
objects.description: Adversaries extort users using data they have gathered. For example, attackers may threaten to leak personal data they have gathered about a user.

objects.name: Extract Contact Information From Response
objects.description: Adversaries utilize account recovery flows to identify the contact information for a certain platform asset. For example, an account recovery flow may include which email address owns the specified asset.

objects.name: Form Social Connections
objects.description: Adversaries perform artificial engagement by forming social connections such as adding or gaining followers, friends or subscribers. By doing so, adversaries reach a larger audience.

objects.name: Impersonate Email Sender
objects.description: Adversaires impersonate an email sender, for example by altering email headers.

objects.name: Include Third-Party SDK
objects.description: Adversaries utilize code provided by a third-party SDK in their violating entity. For example, the SDK may include tracking elements

objects.name: Infer Expected Response Format
objects.description: Adversaries brute-force valid request paths or strings, but may not know which parameters are required for the request to succeed. Adversaries can use verbose error messages to understand which parameter names and value must be sent for a request to succeed.

objects.name: Infer From Obfuscated Contact Point
objects.description: Adversaries infer contact points based on obfuscated contact points provided by the platform. For example, if a platform provides the email address jsm***@com***[.]com on the profile for John Smith, they may infer his email address is jsmith@company[.]com

objects.name: iOS Emulation
objects.description: Adversaries utilize iOS emulation. For example, an abusive entity may be designed to run in Smartface and make requests appear to originate from an iOS device

objects.name: IP Rotation
objects.description: Adversaries rotate the origin IP addresses to avoid detection and rate limits by spreading the traffic over many IPs

objects.name: Join Social Media Group(s)
objects.description: Adversaries join social media groups to identify the users belonging to the group

objects.name: Legacy App
objects.description: Adversaries use legacy versions of an application, likely because it has fewer protections against privacy attacks

objects.name: Legacy Endpoint
objects.description: Attackers may access data through legacy endpoints that may not be as well maintained. For example, older endpoints may have less checks for unbounded count parameters

objects.name: Link Contact Point To Account
objects.description: Adversaries may try to associate contact points with accounts to identify the individual owning the account

objects.name: Locally Cached Data By App
objects.description: Adversaries allow abusive app to store data locally on user's device

objects.name: Merge/Migrate Assets
objects.description: Adversaries merge or migrate assets on the platform in order to force engagement from users.

objects.name: Messaging
objects.description: Adversaries perform artificial engagement by serving messages

objects.name: Modify 2FA Key
objects.description: Adversaries modify the authenication device on the platform asset, usually to preserve their access to that asset. For example, an adversary may add a new phone to recieve 2FA push notifications

objects.name: Pagination Cursor Manipulation
objects.description: Adversaries manipulate pagination cursors in requests, allowing them to scrape greater information from an endpoint and blend in with organic traffic.

objects.name: Parameter Manipulation
objects.description: Adversaries abuse endpoints that allow for certain parameters to be used excessively in a single request. Either repeating the parameter to excess, or cramming more values into a parameter than originally intended. Either one can be used to retrieve significantly more data per request than is expected.

objects.name: Plaintext Data In URL
objects.description: Adversaries collect data from plaintext URL strings. For example, an adversary may gather a public ID by collecting the URL of that profile

objects.name: Private User Data
objects.description: Adversaries access private user data that would not otherwise be available to public users of the platform

objects.name: Privileged Account
objects.description: Adversaries use accounts with special privileges on the platform. For example, attackers may utilize accounts with debug privileges to access additional user logs.

objects.name: Privileged App
objects.description: Adversaries use apps with special privileges on the platform. For example, attackers may utilize first-party apps that are authorized to call special endpoints.

objects.name: Proxy Through First-Party Infrastructure
objects.description: Attackers route traffic through infrastructure provided by the platform itself to evade detection and rate limit systems

objects.name: Public User Data
objects.description: Adversaries access public user data that is accessible to anyone on or off the platform

objects.name: Publish Data to Dark Web
objects.description: Adversaries sell or paste personal data on deep or dark web marketplaces

objects.name: Purchase Access Tokens
objects.description: Adversaries acquire platform access by purchasing session tokens from an access broker

objects.name: Purchase Accounts
objects.description: Adversaries acquire platform access by purchasing pre-made accounts. For example, adversaries may choose to buy aged accounts that appear more legitimate than newly created accounts

objects.name: Reactions
objects.description: Adversaries perform artificial engagement by serving reactions to specified posts and boosting engagement on the post

objects.name: Rebrand App/Service
objects.description: Adversaries attempt to evade detection by rebranding their service

objects.name: Remove 2FA
objects.description: Attackers bypass 2FA by removing 2FA requirements from the user's account to make it easier to access the account.

objects.name: Repeat Requests Until Rate Limit is Triggered
objects.description: Adversaries identify rate limit by sending requests until the late limit is triggered

objects.name: Require users to self-compromise
objects.description: TBD

objects.name: Residential Proxy Service
objects.description: Adversaries use residential proxy services to mask their identity. Residential proxy services may be desired since the malicious traffic blends with real user traffic.

objects.name: Reuse Photos
objects.description: Adversaries reuse photos from authentic assets or figures to legitimize their assets

objects.name: Sharing
objects.description: Adversaries perform artificial engagement by sharing specified posts in order to boost the popularity of the post

objects.name: Social Engineer Support
objects.description: Adversaries use social engineering tactics to impersonate as the real user when speaking to support staff

objects.name: Spoof Account Identifier
objects.description: Adversaries modify account identifiers to appear as another account. For example, having a certain account identifier may allow the adversary to access certain resources

objects.name: Spoof Location
objects.description: Adversaries spoof location data to appear as though they are accessing the platform from certain region

objects.name: Spoof Referrer Header
objects.description: Adversaries send requests with modified referrer headers. For example, platforms may look for specific referrer headers when serving certain sites

objects.name: Spoof Session ID
objects.description: Adversaries spoof their session ID to access resources as another user as part of the user's session. Adversaries may spoof their session ID with the intent of accessing additional resources or hiding their real identity.

objects.name: Spoof URL
objects.description: Adversaries spoof URLs on-platform, for example by using a redirecting domain

objects.name: Spoof User Agent
objects.description: Adversaries spoof user agents to appear as though they are using a certain type of device

objects.name: Test Fake Account Detection
objects.description: Adversaries test fake account detection algorithms. For example, they may try creating accounts with various VPNs or profile photos to test detection capabilities

objects.name: Test Scraping Detection
objects.description: Adversaries test scraping detection algorithms. For example, they may try various forms of scraping with test accounts to see which behaviors trigger detection

objects.name: Test Session Detection
objects.description: Adversaries test session reuse detection algorithms. For example, they may try to hijack sessions from a test user to see what trips the detection algorithms

objects.name: Test User
objects.description: Test users are typically assumed to reside in a sandbox where their functionality is limited. If test users are able to perform some real-user actions, then an attacker can multiply the number of authenticated accounts they can use to perform authenticated activity

objects.name: Trojan App
objects.description: Adversaries market an application to have certain functionality while embedding abusive functionality in the same application

objects.name: Use Affiliate Referral Program
objects.description: Adversaries leverage affiliate referral programs to generate revenue

objects.name: Use Commercial Tooling
objects.description: Adversaries use commercially-available tooling to enable abusive capabilities. For example, they may buy WordPress tools to send requests from many sources

objects.name: Use Open Source Tooling
objects.description: Adversaries use open-source tooling to enable abusive capabilities. For example, they may use Selenium to automate browser traffic

objects.name: Use Private Domain Registration
objects.description: Adversaries use private domain registration services like WhoIs Guard to mask their personal information when registering domains

objects.name: Use Shell Company
objects.description: Adversaries use shell companies to hide their personal information when create corporate entities

objects.name: Use Third-Party Ads
objects.description: Adversaries generate revenue by selling ad space to third-party advertisers

objects.name: Utilize Official Login Integration
objects.description: Adversaries use the official login integration to appear legitimate and enable violating capabilities such as stealing user tokens

objects.name: Wildcard Query
objects.description: Adversaries use wildcards in queries to get more information. Certain queries allow the use of wildcard characters due to the query engine used. For example, certain query engines use the underscore character '_' as a wildcard, while others use the asterisk or even percent signs as wildcards.

objects.name: Word Dictionary
objects.description: Adversaries guess hidden parameters with a word dictionary. By guessing undocumented, but supported, parameters, attackers may be able to retrieve data that was not originally intended for external use.
